content: The Jones Act, part of the Merchant Marine Act of 1920, mandates that vessels transporting cargo within the U.S. must be U.S.-built, owned, and crewed. It protects U.S. shipyards, carriers, and sailors but is debated for increasing costs and limiting ship availability. The Jones Act, part of the Merchant Marine Act of 1920, mandates that vessels transporting cargo within the U.S. must be U.S.-built, owned, and crewed. It has been a contentious issue in recent Congresses due to its impact on building merchant vessels in U.S. shipyards, debates over Puerto Rico's economic challenges, the sinking of the ship El Faro, and discussions about domestic transportation of oil and natural gas. The law's effectiveness in achieving national security goals has also been questioned. The Jones Act of 1920 mandates that vessels transporting cargo domestically in the U.S. must be U.S.-built, owned, and crewed. In May 2018, the Office of Management and Budget requested public comment on federal requirements in the maritime sector to increase efficiency and reduce regulatory burdens. The Jones Act of 1920 requires that cargo transported domestically in the U.S. must be on vessels that are U.S.-built, owned, and crewed. This law originated from legislation dating back to the First Congress in 1789, which favored U.S.-flag fleets over foreign fleets by imposing lesser duties on domestically built and owned vessels. Repairing vessels has been more expensive and time-consuming than projected, prompting consideration of accelerating the purchase of foreign-built ships. The Jones Act and Tariff Act of 1930 aim to support U.S. shipyards by imposing duties on repairs done on U.S. flag ships in foreign yards. Despite the 50% duty, many U.S.-flag international trading ships still opt for repairs in foreign yards due to lower costs compared to domestic shipyards. This trend was confirmed by a U.S.-flag operator in 2018.
